bib_record.title: Determination of the 233-Pa (n, f) reaction cross section from 11.5 to 16.5 MeV neutron energy by the hybrid surrogate ratio approach

free_txt: The 234-Pa and 236-U compound systems have
been populated at overlapping excitation energies in
the same experiment through 232-Th (6-Li,A) 234-Pa and
232-Th (6-Li,D) 236-U transfer channels at E (lab) = 38
MeV, and the absolute surrogate method is used to
determine fission decay probabilities of the above
compound nuclei by dividing the number of PLF-fission
coincidences by the associated PLF-singles data. The
experimental values of fission decay probability
ratios of 234-Pa and 236-U compound nuclei at the same
excitation energies have been used to deduce the 233-Pa
(n,f) cross-section using a surrogate ratio approach.
A new hybrid surrogate ratio approach has been
employed to determine neutron-induced fission cross
sections of 233-Pa in the energy range of 11.5 to
16.5 MeV for the first time. The 233-Pa
cross sections are deduced from the measured
fission decay probabilities ratios of 234-Pa and
236-U compound nuclei using the surrogate ratio
method. The 233-Pa (n,f) cross section data from the
present experiment along with the data from the
literature, covering the neutron energy range of 1.0
to 16.5 MeV have been compared with the predictions
of statistical model code EMPIRE-2.19. While the
present data are consistent with the model
predictions, there is a discrepancy between the
earliear experiment data and EMPIRE-2.19 predictions
in the neutron energy range of 7.0 to 10.0 MeV.
a solid state delta E - E telescope of
thickness 150.0 micro millimeter to 1.0 millimeter was
kept at 90 degree with respect to the beam direction
around the transfer grazing angle to identify the
projectile-like-fragments (PLF). A 16 strip solid
state detector (each strip of size 2.0 X 64.0 mm) was
placed at a back angle covering the laboratory angular
range of 141-158 degree to detect fission fragments in
coincidence with PLFs.
The uncertainties shown in the measured cross
section is due to the statistics of coincidence
counts in each energy beam.
A self-supporting thorium was bombarded with 6-Li
beam of energy 38.0 MeV from a 14 MV Pelletron
accelerator at Mumbai.
The proton, deuteron, triton, alpha and 6-Li
particles are uniquely identified by plotting delta
E against the delta E + E. This plot was transformed
to create an effective particle identification versus
energy plot.
A self-supporting thorium target of thickness 2.0
Mg/cm**2 was bombarded with a 6-Li beam.
